title: SLA Management and Tracking
content:
Service Level Agreements (SLAs) help you maintain response and resolution time commitments to customers.

Setting Up SLAs:

1. Navigate to Settings > SLAs
2. Click 'Create SLA Policy'
3. Define SLA parameters:
   - First Response Time target
   - Resolution Time target
   - Business hours configuration
   - Escalation rules

4. Set Conditions:
   - Apply to specific mailboxes
   - Filter by tags or customer segments
   - Priority-based SLAs
   - VIP customer exceptions

SLA Components:

1. First Response Time (FRT):
   - Time from email receipt to first reply
   - Most critical metric for customer satisfaction
   - Typically ranges from 1-24 hours

2. Resolution Time:
   - Time from receipt to closing the conversation
   - Varies by complexity and priority
   - Can be hours, days, or weeks

3. Business Hours:
   - Define when SLA clock runs
   - Exclude weekends and holidays
   - Set timezone appropriately
   - Pause during off-hours

SLA Status Indicators:

1. On Track (Green):
   - Plenty of time remaining
   - No action needed

2. At Risk (Yellow):
   - Approaching deadline
   - Needs attention soon
   - Typically 80% of time elapsed

3. Breached (Red):
   - Deadline passed
   - Requires immediate action
   - Logged for reporting

Escalation Workflows:

1. Automatic Escalation:
   - Reassign to senior team member
   - Notify supervisor
   - Change priority status
   - Add urgent tag

2. Escalation Triggers:
   - Time-based (X hours before breach)
   - Multiple breaches for same customer
   - High-priority customer at risk

SLA Monitoring:

1. Dashboard View:
   - See all SLA statuses at a glance
   - Sort by urgency
   - Filter by team member or mailbox

2. Notifications:
   - Email alerts for at-risk SLAs
   - Browser notifications
   - Daily digest of SLA performance

3. Reports:
   - SLA compliance rate
   - Breach analysis
   - Team performance
   - Trend over time

Best Practices:

- Set realistic SLA targets based on data
- Different SLAs for different priorities
- Account for complexity in resolution times
- Use automations to help meet SLAs
- Regular team training on SLA importance
- Review and adjust SLAs quarterly
- Celebrate good SLA performance

Common SLA Configurations:

1. Standard Support:
   - FRT: 4 hours
   - Resolution: 24 hours

2. Priority Support:
   - FRT: 1 hour
   - Resolution: 8 hours

3. VIP/Enterprise:
   - FRT: 30 minutes
   - Resolution: 4 hours

Troubleshooting:
- SLA not tracking: Check business hours configuration
- Incorrect times: Verify timezone settings
- Missing alerts: Check notification preferences
- Frequent breaches: Review SLA targets and staffing
